social_posts.post_text: Can’t wait to tell you all about my latest project. I’ve been working on it for the past two years. Lots of R&D, prototypes, wear-testing and refining. I will reveal more in a week or so. I think you'll love it. Stay tuned…@wearpeluva

I promised a while back that I would announce my latest project. Well, here it is. As you probably know, I’ve been a big fan of foot health and the barefoot or minimalist shoe movement for several decades now. I firmly believe that foot comfort and foot health are essential to achieving optimal overall health. Unfortunately, I’ve never really found a shoe that met the three basic criteria I set for myself: comfortable, functional, and stylish.
 
So two years ago, I set out to design and create what I truly believe is the ultimate shoe. It’s been a long, exciting process and it continues to evolve, but I’m thrilled to say I’ve solved the issues that had bothered me about footwear for decades. I’ve built my dream shoe, comfortable, functional, and stylish, and it has exceeded my wildest expectations.
 
The company is called peluva. We have several different styles and colors to choose from. Appropriate for almost any occasion: from the gym, to hiking, to the workplace, or even going out on the town. I’ve worn peluvas exclusively for almost a year now, and they’ve changed my life. I can’t wait for you to try them. Check us out at peluva.com.

#letfeetbefeet #minimalistshoes #movement #peluva

“Genetics may load the gun… but it is our environment that pulls the trigger”. 🔫

On this week’s episode of @radicalhealthradio, @peakprimalhealth talks with @marksissonprimal,  the founding father of the ancestral health movement. 💪

They talk about how Mark’s health journey has changed over the years, the importance of prioritizing protein, how he’s training at 69 years old, his thoughts on TRT, mastering longevity, and how to enjoy the process of life. 

You can find the full episode at RadicalHealthRadio.com! 🔥

#podcast #heathadvice #radicalhealth #healthylifestyle

Play is an important aspect of my workouts. Paddling, fat tire bike riding on the sand, even some of my gym routines. But my favorite form of play is still the disc (frisbee). It's getting a little tough to find a game of ultimate in Miami Beach these days, but I still love tossing it around. A simple session with one or two people offers the chance to sprint, move laterally, squat, lunge, twist, and even jump a little. Real world fitness.

And it's ALWAYS better with my new peluva Strands on. With these new minimalist shoes, I get to feel the ground underneath and to respond to the changes into terrain while strengthening the small muscles in my feet and increasing my range of motion. Most comfortable shoes ever. www.peluva.com

Our dream guest @marksissonprimal joined us on the podcast - what a great time! Check out his new company @wearpeluva and please give our episode with Mark a listen below 👇 

Spotify: https://open.spotify.com/episode/2P0SS1SGDDPy633ybAnI5w

YouTube: https://youtu.be/L34ZksVUga4

My wife @CarrieLynnSisson and I had a great talk with @laurynbosstick and @MichaelBosstick on @tscpodcast Him&Her Show which just dropped today. This was Carrie's first podcast ever and she crushed it. We talked about longevity, our diets (slightly different), our fitness regimens, and what it has taken for us to stay happily together for 35 years. And a ton more... we also introduced our new minimalist shoe company Peluva. @wearpeluva. Hope you enjoy it!

Had an easy day today. Carrie and I went for a walk, but got caught up in seeking out some unusual terrain. We wound up hopping and skipping over riprap lining Govt Cut in Miami Beach. Really put our shoes and our feet to the test. Funny how this was a "day off" and we probably did more by just goofing around than most people do on a regular work out day. Combined Primal Blueprint law number 3, "move frequently at a comfortable pace" and PB law number 6 "play."

I put this up on Twitter, so I figured I'd re-post it here. Turning 70 in a month. Had just gotten in off the water, where I was giving SUP lessons to the Primal Kitchen content team. Sometimes I think my dream job is teaching SUP in Bali at a resort. Then I wake up and realize my dream job is doing exactly what I am doing now. @wearpeluva

I rode road bikes seriously for about 15 years. When my kids were born, I sold my bikes, mostly because I knew the dangers of riding Pacific Coast Highway in Malibu. It was a simple case of risk management. Mountain biking didn't appeal that much, and so I went almost 25 years without riding a bike outside. Then a Miami friend introduced me to riding fat tire bikes on the sand. The first time he took me out for an hour ride he crushed me. I was hooked. I immediately bought a fat bike for myself and have been obsessed with this for the past four years.

You don't really need a helmet, because there are no cars, and because you're biggest risk on the sand is falling over sideways into soft sand. From going too slow! There is no need for special aero bars, since you really can't go that fast. I always disliked that body position, anyway. So I got a set up with a raised handlebar stem and wider handlebars, so I could sit up a little bit more erect. That takes a load off the neck and shoulders.

This is usually the toughest workout I do all week. So, I get some leg work in, and absolutely get some hard cardio in. None of that Zone 2 stuff when I ride. I hang out in zones 4 and 5 for up to an hour when I do go hard. I treat it as my one really hard work out each week. Then I do lots of zone 2 stuff just moving around throughout the day every other day. I feel like my VO2max has increased in the past several years as a result of this strategy.

Just finishing up an amazing family vacation in the Scottish highlands. 19 family members including children, grand children, cousins, in-laws, SOs, etc. Horseback riding, skeet shooting, archery, falconry, extensive hiking, biking, canoeing and stand up paddling in an amazing loch. Once a year, no matter where we are in the world, we get together and spend two weeks adventuring, playing, reconnecting, sharing stories, concerns and laughter and tears. So grateful to be able to do this.

Years ago I set a personal marker for making it: “When I can take meetings in toe shoes.”

I passed that long ago.

Freedom, family, fitness, and some fun in the sun. 🇺🇸 Celebrating the Fourth of July with gratitude for our independence and for the healthy life we get to live every day. Remember, folks, staying active is a celebration in itself. Happy Independence Day from the Sissons!

How I sprint these days 
Rope pull machine on lowest resistance 

Pull max speed for 30 seconds (sometimes a minute)
Rest 
Repeat...

I've always believed that foot health is the stepping stone to optimal overall health. Everything starts with our direct connection to the ground. Despite being a longtime advocate of the minimalist shoe movement, I could never find a shoe that truly ticked all the boxes - comfort, functionality, and style.

That's why I embarked on a journey over two years ago to create what I believe to be the ultimate shoe. And let me tell you, the result has exceeded my wildest expectations.

Just as I created @primalkitchenfoods to change the way millions of people eat, I created Peluva to change the way the world walks.

Having worn @wearpeluva exclusively for over a year now, I can honestly say they've transformed my life. 

Have you ever worn a minimalist shoe?

Embracing chocolate? Yes, you heard it right! 🍫✨ Far from being just an indulgence, dark chocolate is a true powerhouse of nutrients.

1️⃣ Its high-quality fats protect the liver and don't affect LDL cholesterol levels adversely, providing a sweet yet safe treat for your taste buds.

2️⃣ The rich flavanol content in dark chocolate boosts your body's antioxidant capacity, even outshining many famed superfruits. These flavanols also support heart health, improve blood pressure and promote good circulation.

3️⃣ Want a gut-health hero? Look no further. Dark chocolate is a fantastic source of fiber and polyphenols, acting as prebiotic fuel for your gut's beneficial bacteria.

4️⃣ Regular consumption of dark chocolate is linked to a lowered risk of cardiovascular diseases, improved insulin resistance, and even protection against UV damage - talk about a multitasking marvel!

5️⃣ Finally, for those golden years, dark chocolate is your ally. From improved cognitive function to reducing the risk of type 2 diabetes, this delicious treat helps to age gracefully.

So go ahead and savor that dark chocolate. What's your favorite? #WorldChocolateDay

People think of exercise as something you add to your life, an intervention. The real intervention—the experimental condition we're running on the entire world—is sitting around all day. Exercise is just a restoration of normalcy.

Here's a new perspective for you - 'All Training is Cardio'.

Your heart is the engine of your body. It adjusts and adapts based on the level of activity your brain chooses to engage in, delivering the right amount of oxygen and fuel required to complete that activity. It's always there, quietly keeping pace with your every move.

This means that regardless of the intensity, from lifting weights to sprinting, you're doing cardio work the entire time. It's time we redefine 'cardio exercise', as all exercise, by default, involves your cardiac muscle. So next time you hit the gym, remember - your heart is in it just as much as you are.

Goals are great. Everyone should have 1. In fact, everyone should have many over a lifetime. And strive for them. But don't let goals get in the way of you living & loving your life. Life happens in the small moments. The ones you might tend to miss while you have your head down and your nose to the grindstone. A goal sets you on a course, a journey that is to be experienced fully, with full awareness of everything else around you. Good and bad. I see many business people brag about their 90-hour work weeks in pursuit of big business goals, only to miss out on their kids’ childhood. That loss of time and connection saddens me. Don’t lose those moments. It’s really what life is about.

It’s also important to release attachment to your goals. Yes, give it everything you can, but don’t beat yourself up if you fail. The fact that you tried and failed doesn't negate your effort or your life. Let it go and move on to the next one. Pivot. Reframe. Redirect that energy. Hundreds of thousands of people try to win Olympic gold. Only a few can do it. Does that mean that all the rest are somehow failures? Of course not. Most businessmen will tell you that they learned more from their failures than from their successes. I certainly have.

Ironically, one of the problems with achieving a big goal is that it ends that particular journey. There is a sadness when a goal is achieved and that journey ends. The mind starts to think “what now? Do I need to surpass that goal and rise even higher? Do I retire?” Endurance racing has a lot of that. You win a race and there’s a short-term elation. But a few days later there’s often a depression - the expectation in your mind that you must start another journey. And that’s not a bad thing…just be prepared for it.

When I sold Primal Kitchen to Kraft in 2019, I achieved a huge goal. I was financially set for the rest of my life. But a few days later I became depressed as I contemplated my “retirement” and realized that was not the journey I wanted. With that in mind, I started my new shoe company Peluva with my son Kyle. Our goal is to change the way the world walks. Sometimes goals have to be really lofty….

Ever wondered about the deep connections between what you eat and how your mind and body function? Excited to share my recent conversation with Nick Green of @thrivemarket where we explore the primal philosophy of eating, and its transformative effects on our health and well-being. From shifting mindsets to transforming bodies, this podcast episode has it all. 

I was an early investor in Thrive, and Nick was an early adopter of Primal Kitchen products. We launched our businesses at about the same time and became a prime example of the synergies possible when two brands with a shared ethos fully support each other. Neither of us would have grown as quickly and efficiently without each other. Thanks, Nick!

It just went up on Apple Podcasts & Spotify.

I never thought much about turning 70. Somehow 70 seemed so far out there, so distant into the future that I never paid attention to the passage of time in that context. I guess I was too busy living my life, per my last post. I do remember thinking 30 years ago “I want to show people what 70 can look like. Not just from a physical perspective, but from a philosophical perspective.” Well, that day has finally arrived. There’s so much to say on this that I will reserve most of it for a long blog post or a book. But here are a few thoughts:

First, regarding longevity, I don’t harbor any deep desire to live to 140 or 160. You biohackers go for it. I’m not willing to pursue unproven hedonistic sacrifices or engage in bizarre regimens in hopes that I might extract few extra days of life on the back end. As e e cummings said, “there is some shit I will not eat.” I will be content with 25 or 30 more years of good mobility and cognition.  I don’t fear death. It’s the finality that gives life meaning. Awareness of our imminent mortality provides an obligatory opportunity to find those moments of joy, happiness, contentment and meaning that ultimately define a life well lived.

Secondly, I have long asserted that one of our most important human obligations (and joys) is to have children; to pass our genes along to the next generation, as every organism is bound to do. No judgement on those unable or unwilling to have kids, but I will say that having children was the best and most important thing Carrie and I have done. And yet, it wasn’t until we had grandchildren that I really understood the “circle of life thing.” Seeing your children have their own children and pass their genes along really completes that circle. It’s as Primal as it gets.

Anyway, make no mistake, I fully plan to be hammering away for another good 20 or 30 years. Despite a few aches and pains, I “feel” the best I’ve ever felt. 70 is the new 40.

Balancing life is an art, just as much as maintaining physical balance is a skill. We're defying gravity every step of our day, from the office to the shower, on the streets or on our bikes. Our balance keeps us grounded, resilient, and safe. But have you paused to think how it all works? 

Strength, vision, inner ear fluid, nerves, and the brain all conspire to keep us upright and moving with grace. As we age, our balance can falter, but there are ways to reclaim it. Sleep well, move deliberately, strengthen your body, incorporate balance practices into your everyday, and spend time barefoot to keep those feet flexible and alert.

Beyond the physical, balance is a metaphor for life: the equilibrium between striving and resting, working and playing, eating well and enjoying a treat. So today, let's celebrate the art of balance. Let's challenge it, test it, appreciate it and nurture it. How do you maintain your balance?

I spent a large part of my life engaged in high level running and cycling. Always chasing the higher heart-rate goals, generally eschewing walking as a "less than optimal" use of my time. Man, has that changed!  In past few decades, partly as a result of my own willingness to slow down a bit and partly a result of my research into what constitutes true heart health, what defines human biomechanics and what ultimately delivers the biggest bang for the buck, I've realized that walking is one of the most quintessentially human activities we can do. Of course, I still cycle (fat bike), lift and SUP, but walking has become a cornerstone of my wellness philosophy. It's elegantly simple and universally accessible. Carrie and I are in the south of France for the summer and we cover anywhere from 6 to 12 miles a day walking roads, dirt paths, rocky mountain trails and beaches. We genuinely look forward to it as the highlight of each day. 

In a perfect world, we would be doing all this barefoot, but the fact is that manmade surfaces like pavement, concrete, tile, hardwood floors, etc make it difficult to cover that amount of ground from day to day without discomfort. That's one of the reasons I designed peluvas: to give myself (and everyone else) a true barefoot-like "groundfeel" to every step, but still allow for comfort, functionality and protection from the elements. Peluvas just make me want to walk more; the pleasure of each stride is magnified. 

I believe we're standing at the precipice of a revolution in our walking habits. Join us in this transformation. Lace up your @wearpeluva and take that first step towards a healthier stride and a more enjoyable day.

First off, let’s settle one thing right away. Grilling is not the same as barbecuing. Barbecue means big cuts of meat cooked low and slow. Depending on the animal, it can be an all-day affair with hours of preparation and plenty of leisure. In other words, it’s an actual event. With the time and labor intensity, barbecuing (as Michael Pollan put it so well recently) is the stuff of primal ritual, the site of social cohesion in our evolutionary story. Grilling, on the other hand, offers the smoke and fire experience without the bigger doings. While not as idyllic a prospect, it’s convenient. It means throwing a steak on the grill after work and eating it 20 minutes later. That’s the beauty of grilling. It’s relatively quick, requires very little cleanup, and lets you kick back outdoors while cooking dinner. 

In order to relax, however, it’s good to be confident that dinner won’t go up in flames. Luckily, what separates someone who burns dinner from a real grill master is simply practice, plus a few tips and techniques. 

Most of the smaller cuts of meat at the meat counter cook well on a grill, like steaks, short ribs, pork and lamb chops, and chicken pieces. A good butcher can guide you to the best cuts for grilling in your price range. Then, of course, there’s seafood, burgers of all types, sausage, and veggies. You can throw almost anything on a grill—even fruit. 

No matter what you’re grilling, these tips and techniques apply... 

#nationalgrillingday

I mentioned the other day that Carrie and I are in France now, but prior to that we had a magical family holiday in the Highlands of Scotland where we scaled mountains, crossed wet peat bogs, traversed trails and made memories to last a lifetime. Of the 20 family members in attendance, at least 15 wore @wearpeluva most of the time. It was our biggest "wear-testing" yet and was a huge success. They held up through every pebble-strewn path, every craggy rock, every deep wet bog and every mossy mound, proving that comfort, style and practicality can co-exist in one shoe. Here's to embracing nature with every stride.

Sometimes the best conversations are the silent ones. A rendezvous with wisdom personified, right on my shoulder. Reminding me of Athena's trusted companion, an emblem of insight and knowledge. This encounter made me appreciate the power of observation, the virtue of silence, and the depth of understanding.

Can't help but ponder, if we were more like this sage old bird, how much more of the world's truth we could uncover? 🦉

@marksissonprimal on why wearing a barefoot style shoes is beneficial for foot strength and health in general. In this episode Mark discusses Primal Kitchen, seed oils, and feet. Check out the whole episode on Apple, Substack, Rumble, and Spotify. #eatprimal #footstrength #hiking #running #tradlife #primalkitchen #ssedoils #vegan #carnivore #aging

I recently tried clay pigeon shooting in the Scottish Highlands. It’s not just about hitting the target - it’s about maintaining balance along the way. My @Peluva shoes were a huge help, keeping my stance steady and secure. The wide toe base and minimalist sole helped me connect with the ground so all I had to think about was the shot.   

#wearpeluva #primalblueprint #primalliving #marksdailyapple #primallifestyle

Can’t wait for you guys to tune in and join the conversation. The full episode can be found in the link in my bio.  Take a listen and let me know what you think.

Recently on the @primalkitchenfoods Podcast, @morganzanotti posed a profound question: “If it all went away, then what?” It forced me to reflect on what truly sparks joy and happiness. The answer? It’s something money can’t buy. It’s a deep sense of contentment and fulfillment you have to discover within yourself. Cherishing these invaluable moments with @carrielynnsisson is a constant reminder of this truth.

What’s your answer to that question? The full episode can be found in the link in my bio. Take a listen and let me know what you think.

@carrielynnsisson and I had a fabulous lunch date at Le Dauphin restaurant in Cap Ferrat. Of course, we were wearing matching blue @wearpeluva Strand shoes which were comfortable, stylish and the perfect shoe for the walk to and from the restaurant. Of course, Carrie also brought her designer sandals to wear poolside. 

📷@pamelajonesphoto

Now that I don't run much anymore, I have rediscovered the magic of walking. It's incredible, and I wish I had started seriously 30 years ago. I always thought of walking as "less than ideal" for fitness. To the contrary, it's probably the best thing we can all do. And it's something that Carrie and I can do together. We walk several (5-10) miles a day nearly every day when we are on vacation. Obviously, we are wearing our @wearpeluva Strands for maximum groundfeel and comfort. These shoes literally make me want to walk. The hike we took today was one of the more scenic routes in the world. And we have the luxury of pretty much doing it whenever we want.

In today’s world, wearable health tracking devices have become ubiquitous, promising to make our lives easier, healthier, and more informed. But have you ever considered the downside?

While these devices can provide valuable insights into our health and fitness, they can also have unintended consequences that are often overlooked. In addition to privacy concerns to accuracy issues, the potential for obsessive behavior, relying too heavily on these devices can exacerbate anxiety and unhealthy habits, leading to a negative impact on mental, emotional, and social well-being.

It’s important to approach health tracking mindfully and with caution, recognizing the benefits while also acknowledging the potential drawbacks. Let’s have an open conversation about the implications of wearable devices and work towards a healthy balance between their use and our overall physical and emotional well-being. Do you wear any kind of health-tracking device? What’s your experience? Tell us in the comments!

 These innovative shoes are designed to give your feet the freedom they deserve, all while providing the support and protection you need. Whether you're a seasoned athlete or just someone who enjoys an active lifestyle, Peluva Barefoot Toe Shoes are a game-changer.

What sets Peluva apart from the rest? It's all about the toes! These shoes are specially crafted to allow each of your toes to move independently, mimicking the natural movement of your feet. This not only enhances your balance and stability but also helps prevent common foot problems.

But here's the best part: right now, you can head over to Peluva.com and use the discount code LIVEKINETICALLY to get an exclusive 10% off your order. That's right, folks, 10% off just for being a part of the Kinetic Coach Dan community!

I was so inspired and happy with the shoe and the way that my body felt that I decided to wear them when I played tennis. A+ Peluva.

At 70 as a lifelong endurance athlete and serial entrepreneur, @marksissonprimal knows a thing or two we can all learn from. He seems to have it all, a beautiful family, a gorgeous and supportive partner, and several successful businesses including @primalkitchenfoods which sold for an amount that he could have ridden off into the sunset with but instead, he’s back in the entrepreneur/founder seat with @wearpeluva, always out here educating us on optimal living. 

His advice and perspective on how to have it all is one I feel everyone should check out, business owner or not.

Check it out anywhere you get your podcasts or by visiting eatplaycrush.com/podcast | MARK SISSON: ENTREPRENEURSHIP, HAVING IT ALL, AND FOOT HEALTH (MEET PELUVA)

today’s episode w/ @marksissonprimal & @carrielynnsisson 🎧 such an inspiring episode for me - mark & carrie talk about having the best sex of their lives at 68 & 70, marriage advice, looking great naked, peptides & stem cells, cold plunges, foot health & so much more.
